channel.title: Using both my speaker jacks together
channel.description:
My computer has two jacks for speakers, one at the back and a headphone jack in the front. I want to be able to use both for VirtualDj. I can't seem to get it working nor can I use both from testing it in Windows Audio settings. They both work but only one at a time (if I had something plugged in the back and the front, only the front headphone jack will work).
What can I do to get both working without having to buy another sound card or spending any money?

item.title: Using both my speaker jacks together
item.dc:creator: @PaulT PaulT
item.description:
@PaulT wrote:

It’s a pain in the ass to get this to work. Get a splitter.

Read full topic
item.source: Using both my speaker jacks together

item.title: Using both my speaker jacks together
item.dc:creator: @HcoJustin HcoJustin
item.description:
@HcoJustin wrote:

[quote="-Nothing, post:8, topic:547097"][quote author=HcoJustin link=topic=665996.msg4452759#msg4452759 date=1412671403]

Right click the sound icon on your tray, select playback devices. See if you can enable them both at same time.

If the port on the front of the case is the one wired directly to the motherboard it won’t work. Those are designed to have exclusive access to the integrated sound card.

https://www.google.com/search?q=Using+both+my+speaker+jacks+together

Others seem to think otherwise.

Out of everything on the first page, half of those aren’t even related. The other half are for Realtek cards, which is great if OP has one. Assuming your card supports it, you’ll also need the Realtek drivers, and you need to use their audio manager.
[/quote]
II believe most of the integrated sound cards nowadays are from Realtek, so there’s a big chance OP has one too.

Can you link me to a topic where it states that front panel overrides back panel jacks? I personally couldn’t find any, then again I probably used wrong search terms.[/quote]
http://superuser.com/questions/120602/how-to-get-headphones-and-speakers-working-at-the-same-time

Most Realtek cards have two settings:
Make front and rear output devices playback two different audio streams simultaneously
Make front and rear output devices playback the same audio stream (default)

They also have front panel jack detection turned on by default, which will disable the back one when it detects something plugged in up front. Again these settings can only be changed with the Realtek drivers, and using their audio manager. If you use the default windows drivers you won’t have access to these settings even with a card that supports it

Read full topic
item.source: Using both my speaker jacks together

item.title: Using both my speaker jacks together
item.dc:creator: @Ashi Ashi
item.description:
@Ashi wrote:

[quote="-Nothing, post:8, topic:547097"][quote author=HcoJustin link=topic=665996.msg4452759#msg4452759 date=1412671403]

Right click the sound icon on your tray, select playback devices. See if you can enable them both at same time.

If the port on the front of the case is the one wired directly to the motherboard it won’t work. Those are designed to have exclusive access to the integrated sound card.

https://www.google.com/search?q=Using+both+my+speaker+jacks+together

Others seem to think otherwise.

Out of everything on the first page, half of those aren’t even related. The other half are for Realtek cards, which is great if OP has one. Assuming your card supports it, you’ll also need the Realtek drivers, and you need to use their audio manager.
[/quote]
II believe most of the integrated sound cards nowadays are from Realtek, so there’s a big chance OP has one too.

Can you link me to a topic where it states that front panel overrides back panel jacks? I personally couldn’t find any, then again I probably used wrong search terms.[/quote]
Okay in sound manager thingy only one sound driver is there. That is for both. There is no topic that states this, headphone jack (the front jacks) usually in most cases always overide the main (back in my case). I’ve tested this.

I don’t think I’m using realtek soundcard.

Read full topic
item.source: Using both my speaker jacks together
